abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Enterprise and
            Financial Sector Restructuring Project is rated highly
            satisfactory, because of its successful design and
            execution, and the creative course correction achieved
            during its implementation. Key lessons learned include: 1)
            It is important to put in place good management and a good
            management structure in complex institution-building
            projects. 2) This project suffers from misunderstanding of
            complex Bank disbursement procedures. These added to the
            transaction costs of the credit line and slowed down the
            lending process. Both disbursement and procurement
            procedures need to be simplified as far as possible. 3) In
            terms of project design, the need for flexible management
            and willingness to find solutions by refining the design are
            important lessons of experience for all financial
            intermediary loans (FILs). 4) The course correction came as
            a result of good quality supervision which in turn benefited
            from continuity. It is a feature of institution building
            projects such as FILs that intensive continuous supervision
            is essential. 5) The intervention of the Bank may not be
            feasible in a highly competitive financial market. The
            "window of opportunity" for the Bank needs to be
            carefully judged, and speed is needed to take advantage of
            it. 6) Where working capital finance is an integral part of
            an enterprise's investment program, it should be
            regarded as performing the same function as fixed capital.
